lines.text: Enter CORIOLANUS with Patricians

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Let them puff all about mine ears, present me Death on the wheel or at wild horses heels, Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock, That the precipitation might down stretch Below the beam of sight, yet will I still Be thus to them.

lines.speaker: a patrician
lines.text: You do the nobler.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: I muse my mother Does not approve me further, who was wont To call them woollen vassals, things created To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads In congregations, to yawn, be still and wonder, When one but of my ordinance stood up To speak of peace or war. I talk of you: Why did you wish me milder would you have me False to my nature Rather say I play The man I am.
Enter VOLUMNIA

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: O, sir, sir, sir, I would have had you put your power well on, Before you had worn it out.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Let go.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: You might have been enough the man you are, With striving less to be so lesser had been The thwartings of your dispositions, if You had not showd them how ye were disposed Ere they lackd power to cross you.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Let them hang.

lines.speaker: a patrician
lines.text: Ay, and burn too.
Enter MENENIUS and Senators

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough You must return and mend it.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Theres no remedy Unless, by not so doing, our good city Cleave in the midst, and perish.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Pray, be counselld: I have a heart as little apt as yours, But yet a brain that leads my use of anger To better vantage.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Well said, noble woman Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that The violent fit o the time craves it as physic For the whole state, I would put mine armour on, Which I can scarcely bear.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: What must I do

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Return to the tribunes.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Well, what then what then

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Repent what you have spoke.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: For them! I cannot do it to the gods Must I then dot to them

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: You are too absolute Though therein you can never be too noble, But when extremities speak. I have heard you say, Honour and policy, like unseverd friends, I the war do grow together: grant that, and tell me, In peace what each of them by the other lose, That they combine not there.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Tush, tush!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: A good demand.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: If it be honour in your wars to seem The same you are not, which, for your best ends, You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse, That it shall hold companionship in peace With honour, as in war, since that to both It stands in like request

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Why force you this

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Because that now it lies you on to speak To the people not by your own instruction, Nor by the matter which your heart prompts you, But with such words that are but rooted in Your tongue, though but bastards and syllables Of no allowance to your bosoms truth. Now, this no more dishonours you at all Than to take in a town with gentle words, Which else would put you to your fortune and The hazard of much blood. I would dissemble with my nature where My fortunes and my friends at stake required I should do so in honour: I am in this, Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles And you will rather show our general louts How you can frown than spend a fawn upon em, For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard Of what that want might ruin.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Noble lady! Come, go with us speak fair: you may salve so, Not what is dangerous present, but the loss Of what is past.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: I prithee now, my son, Go to them, with this bonnet in thy hand And thus far having stretchd ithere be with them Thy knee bussing the stonesfor in such business Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant More learned than the earswaving thy head, Which often, thus, correcting thy stout heart, Now humble as the ripest mulberry That will not hold the handling: or say to them, Thou art their soldier, and being bred in broils Hast not the soft way which, thou dost confess, Were fit for thee to use as they to claim, In asking their good loves, but thou wilt frame Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far As thou hast power and person.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: This but done, Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours For they have pardons, being askd, as free As words to little purpose.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Prithee now, Go, and be ruled: although I know thou hadst rather Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf Than flatter him in a bower. Here is Cominius.
Enter COMINIUS

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: I have been i the marketplace and, sir,tis fit You make strong party, or defend yourself By calmness or by absence: alls in anger.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Only fair speech.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: I think twill serve, if he Can thereto frame his spirit.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: He must, and will Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce Must I with base tongue give my noble heart A lie that it must bear Well, I will dot: Yet, were there but this single plot to lose, This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it And throwt against the wind. To the marketplace! You have put me now to such a part which never I shall discharge to the life.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Come, come, well prompt you.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said My praises made thee first a soldier, so, To have my praise for this, perform a part Thou hast not done before.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Well, I must dot: Away, my disposition, and possess me Some harlots spirit! my throat of war be turnd, Which quired with my drum, into a pipe Small as an eunuch, or the virgin voice That babies lulls asleep! the smiles of knaves Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys tears take up The glasses of my sight! a beggars tongue Make motion through my lips, and my armd knees, Who bowd but in my stirrup, bend like his That hath received an alms! I will not dot, Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth And by my bodys action teach my mind A most inherent baseness.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: At thy choice, then: To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour Than thou of them. Come all to ruin let Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list Thy valiantness was mine, thou suckdst it from me, But owe thy pride thyself.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Pray, be content: Mother, I am going to the marketplace Chide me no more. Ill mountebank their loves, Cog their hearts from them, and come home beloved Of all the trades in Rome. Look, I am going: Commend me to my wife. Ill return consul Or never trust to what my tongue can do I the way of flattery further.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Do your will.
Exit

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Away! the tribunes do attend you: arm yourself To answer mildly for they are prepared With accusations, as I hear, more strong Than are upon you yet.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: The word is mildly. Pray you, let us go: Let them accuse me by invention, I Will answer in mine honour.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Ay, but mildly.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Well, mildly be it then. Mildly!
Exeunt
